_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cambrex Charles City, Inc, (formally Salsbury Chemicals, Inc) a subsidiary of Cambrex Corporation, manufactures chemicals    for use in animal feed additives, human pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals. The company also develops and manufactures active pharmaceutical ingredients, fine chemicals and pharmaceutical intermediates   for a wide range of applications. Cambrex Charles City (CCC) maintains administrative offices, research &      development and manufacturing facilities in Charles City, Iowa and markets products globally.

Dr. Joseph Salsbury, a veterinarian, founded Dr. Salsbury's Laboratories in 1929.  Salsbury remained family          owned until     Solvay and Cie, a Belgium company, purchased it in 1979.  The name was changed to Solvay Animal     Health, Inc. (SAH) in  1987.  In 1991, Cambrex Corporation acquired the chemical production assets from SAH.  The division was renamed   Salsbury  Chemicals, Inc. in 1991 and renamed Cambrex Charles City, Inc in 2002, and remains a wholly owned subsidiary of    Cambrex Corporation.

CCC is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for employees, the public, and the environment.  As a     part of this   commitment, CCC has established a system to help ensure the safe operation of the Charles City Plant. One    part of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage risks at the Charles City Plant and     that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's  (EPA's) rule 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a risk   management plan describing the risk management program at the Charles City     Plant.  This document is    intended to satisfy the requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a     description of the risk management  program and activities at the Charles City Plant.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Po

licies

CCC is committed to the safety of its employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment,       through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  CCC implements reasonable controls to prevent    foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of a significant accidental release, CCC evacuates workers and contacts the local fire and police departments to control and contain the release and to prevent    and/or reduce the consequences of the release.
 
CCC's commitment is manifested further in our use of sound operating and maintenance practices, use of safety-conscious designs as well as extensive employee training.  In addition, we perform periodic safety audits and investigate all incidents and integrate lessons learned into our operations to further minimize risks to employees,    the environment, and the community.

CCC operates its plant in an environment that promotes safety, shows respect for employees, encourages       individual development and supports teamwork to achieve common goals. We know that the ongoing health and safety of  our     employees and environmental compliance is critical to our success.  Thus, CCC manages our business     in a manner     conscious of current and future environmental needs so that we are an asset to our community     through our business  practices and local involvement.

We continuously improve our practices in light of advances in technology and new understandings in safety,    health, and environmental science.  We make consistent measurable progress in implementing this commitment throughout our  operations.  CCC is a member of the American Chemistry Council and the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturers Association and adheres to the Responsible Care program, which is a requirement for       membership in these industry organizations.

Responsible Care is a cornerstone of CCC's environmental, health, and safety (ES&H) management systems.      It is a chemic

al industry initiative through which companies commit to a continuous effort to improve their      responsible management of chemicals.  The program began in Canada in the late 1980's and has since spread around the globe.  It has rapidly become    the single most important performance improvement program within the chemical industry.

In adopting Responsible Care, CCC has agreed to conduct its business according to the following principles:

* To recognize and respond to community concerns about chemicals and our operations

* To develop and produce chemicals that can be manufactured, transported, and disposed of safely

* To make health, safety, and environmental considerations a priority in our planning for all existing and new     products and processes

* To report promptly to officials, employees, and customers and the public, information on chemical-related     health or environmental hazards and to recommend proactive measures

* To counsel customers on the use, transportation, and disposal of chemical products

* To operate our plants and facilities in a manner that protects the environment, health, and safety or our        employees and the public

* To extend our knowledge by conducting or supporting research on the health, safety, and environmental effects    of our products, processes, and waste material

* To work with others to resolve problems created by past handling and disposal of hazardous substances

* To participate with the government and others in creating responsible laws, regulations, and standards to      safeguard the community, workplace, and environment

* To promote the principles of Responsible Care by sharing experiences and offering assistance to others who      produce, handle, use, transport, or dispose of chemicals

While these principles give shape to Responsible Care, they require supporting action.  All Responsible Care signatories agree to enact six codes of management practices.  CCC is proud of its record of accomplishment

in      this regard by having implemented all six codes.

Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER) Code
CCC is an active participant on the regional LEPC and maintains an open dialogue with local first responders.       The Company also routinely hosts site visits for first responders as well as community tours.
 
Process Safety Code
CCC has invested in process safety by implementing management practices that address the identification and evaluation of hazards, the prevention of chemical accidents, and the management of risks to employees, the community, and the environment.  These management practices involve extensive employee training, process   hazard analysis, written operating and maintenance procedures, safe work practices, management of change,       incident investigation, and periodic audits.

Employee Health and Safety Code
Our overall injury rates are consistently well below the average rates for similar-sized companies in the chemical industry.  CCC's average OSHA Incident Rate for the past five years is 1.7.

Pollution Prevention Code
CCC maintains a system to establish specific process and facility-wide waste reduction and pollution prevention goals and to track our progress in meeting these goals.  Our successes achieved through employee-driven         teams include significant increases in the amount of recycled by-products, reductions in the amount of waste requiring     off-site disposal, and reduced air emissions.

Distribution Code
We maintain a common carrier and distribution facility qualification and selection program to minimize risks from    the handling and shipping of our products.  During the Responsible Care Management Systems Verification     (MSV),   CCC was recognized by the American Chemistry Council for our carrier qualification efforts.

Product Stewardship Code
CCC places strong emphasis on proper handling of our products throughout the organization.  We continue to    place our Sales and Marketing organizations as the

focal point for customer contact on safety information,      allowing them to focus internal resources to best assist customers.

1.2 CCC Chemicals Plant and Regulated Substances

CCC's plant is located on a 45-acre site on the southwestern edge of  town.  In order to manufacture a range of      bulk active pharmaceutical ingredients, CCC stores and handles one RMP-regulated substance in an RMP-covered      process.  Polyallylamine hydrochloride was first manufactured at Salsbury in July 1997.  However, increased     product demands have caused us to employ this process at greater production rates, which requires that we store the RMP-regulated substance, allylamine, on site in an amount that exceeds EPA's RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.  We store about 43,000 lbs.     Of allylamine, a toxic and flammable substance, in a 7,500     gal. bulk storage tank at atmospheric pressure. The bulk storage tank and associated process equipment has a maximum intended inventory of 60,000 lbs and is regulated as a single EPA     RMP Program 3 process.

1.3  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

CCC maintains a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and to ensure safe operation:

Process Safety Information - CCC maintains up-to-date, easily accessible versions of a variety of important chemical process information concerning chemical hazards, process technology, and process equipment so that our employees can effectively perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Process Hazard Analysis - CCC performs team-based hazard analyses on the allylamine process using industry best-practice methods.  A management safety committee evaluates the results and resolves and implements     safety improvements on a timely basis.  CCC updates its hazard analysis when significant process changes warrant,     but no less often than every five years.

Operating Procedures - We maintain written operating procedures for our employees to use and we

annually     certify the procedures to be accurate and up-to-date.

Training - CCC has thorough initial and refresher training programs and we document that our employees understand the training they receive.

Mechanical Integrity - CCC has a formal system to maintain the ongoing integrity of our process equipment.  Our     well-trained maintenance personnel, using best practice procedures and high quality tools and materials, perform     regular inspections, tests, and preventive maintenance activities.  We document the results of these inspections and    watch closely for and correct equipment deficiencies that could affect safe operation.

Management of Change - CCC follows a written procedure to evaluate proposed changes to our process to       mange our risks and to ensure that new hazards are not introduced.

Pre-startup Safety Review - Following significant changes prior to startup, we perform safety reviews to ensure     that all equipment is ready, procedures have been modified as needed, appropriate training has been done, and      process hazards have been evaluated and managed.

Compliance Audits - CCC performs audits of its process safety management system at least every 3 years and    we certify that we have evaluated compliance and corrected any deficiencies.

Incident Investigation - In the event of an allylamine release or a "near-miss", we thoroughly investigate the     incident, determine root causes, and implement improvements to preclude recurrence.

Employee Participation - CCC knows that safety starts with its employees - the first line of defense against      accidental releases.  We consult with our employees and determine the appropriate involvement of workers in all accident prevention activities.

Hot Work Permit - CCC follows procedures to ensure that spark-producing work in areas containing allylamine do not result in fires or explosions.

Contractors - CCC maintains an effective contractors safety program that evaluates the safety prog

ram and performance of potential contractor firms, provides necessary site safety information to help ensure that their        work can be completed safety when on site, and periodically evaluates the contractor's safety/job performance.

In addition to the safety management system described above, CCC employs several chemical-specific prevention    and mitigation technologies to reduce the risk of allylamine releases:

* Equipment constructed to appropriate codes and standards
* Fire prevention sprinkler system
* Storage tank dike and unloading area containment area and sump
* Remotely-operated shutoff valves to quickly isolate leaking piping and equipment
* Operators  equipped with appropriate personal protective equipment to ensure quick emergency response

The CCC accident prevention program and chemical-specific steps outlined above also adhere to OSHA's        process safety management standard and ACC's Responsible Care program.

1.4  Five-Year Accident History

CCC maintains an effective incident investigation program to identify the root causes of incidents and       near-misses and to determine corrective actions to preclude the incidents from recurring.  No releases of allylamine have     occurred from the Charles City Plant in the past five years that have resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known deaths injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site.

1.5 Emergency Response Program

CCC coordinates emergency response procedures with the Charles City Fire Department and with the North     Central Regional Emergency Planning District.  CCC plant employees receive significant training to respond to   minor spill events that do not have a potential for significant effects (e.g., small leaks).  In the event of a larger release, workers evacuate the area and contact the fire department and other local and regional emergency response    officials.

1.6  Planned Changes to I

mprove Safety

CCC constantly strives to improve the safety of its plant and processes through several formal and informal    means.  A CCC management safety committee receives ideas for improvement via the following:  process    hazard analyses, management of change reviews, pre-startup safety reviews, incident investigations,  and periodic     safety audits. We also maintain a program soliciting safety suggestions from workers.  Suggestions for improving safety are reviewed by the safety management committee, acted on expeditiously in a consensus fashion, and tracked to completion.
